item.title: Two Decades After Its Release, ‚ÄòThe Art Book for Children‚Äô Gets a Vibrant Makeover
item.dc:creator: ross
item.description: All images courtesy of Phaidon, shared with permission First published in 1997, Phaidon‚Äôs The Art Book has long been a go-to source for introductions to some of the most influential artists. Spanning medieval to modern times, the volume contains more than 600 works and is available in 20 languages. About two decades ago, the iconic […]
item.content:encoded:
All images courtesy of Phaidon, shared with permission

First published in 1997, Phaidon‚Äôs The Art Book has long been a go-to source for introductions to some of the most influential artists. Spanning medieval to modern times, the volume contains more than 600 works and is available in 20 languages. About two decades ago, the iconic title received another type of translation geared specifically toward younger art lovers when editors released The Art Book for Children.

That kids‚Äô edition presents a bite-sized, accessible version of The Art Book and was recently updated and revised. The new volume features 30 artists from its predecessor along with 30 additions, bringing together the most significant names from art history like Katsushika Hokusai, Jackson Pollock, and Frida Kahlo. Each spread includes one or more works by each artist and a fun, informative text, inviting children to look closely and discover a variety of paintings, sculptures, photographs, and more.

The Art Book for Children will be released on May 22 and is available for pre-order in the Colossal Shop.

¬†

Katsushika Hokusai

Vincent Van Gogh

Artemisia Gentileschi, ‚ÄúEsther Before Ahasuerus‚Äù (1622), oil on canvas

Do stories and artists like this matter to you? Become a Colossal Member today and support independent arts publishing for as little as $5 per month. The article Two Decades After Its Release, ‚ÄòThe Art Book for Children‚Äô Gets a Vibrant Makeover appeared first on Colossal.

item.title: Jason Limon Gets to the Heart of Human Emotion in His Soul-Stirring Skeleton Paintings
item.dc:creator: ross
item.description: ‚ÄúPeas In A Pod‚Äù 10 x 10 inches. All images ¬© Jason Limon, shared with permission Reaching toward universal experiences unclouded by specific identities, Jason Limon strips his recurring characters to the bare bones. The San Antonio-based artist (previously) continues his uncanny paintings of skeletons, who find themselves in precarious, startling, and genial situations. Recent […]
item.content:encoded:
‚ÄúPeas In A Pod‚Äù 10 x 10 inches. All images ¬© Jason Limon, shared with permission

Reaching toward universal experiences unclouded by specific identities, Jason Limon strips his recurring characters to the bare bones. The San Antonio-based artist (previously) continues his uncanny paintings of skeletons, who find themselves in precarious, startling, and genial situations. Recent works include ‚ÄúPeas In A Pod,‚Äù which features two friends adopting new heads from a large, curved shell. Similar smiling orbs appear in ‚ÄúThe Right Grape‚Äù as a character chooses and fits the cheerful green fruit onto its neck.

Working in acrylic paint, Limon conjures myriad textures, whether through the deckled edges of a paper-craft structure or thin, crinkled plastic wrap. Combined with his muted palette of neutrals and jewel tones, these three-dimensional effects imbue the scenes with a vintage charm and a sense of timelessness.

Limon is currently working on a few personal projects, so keep an eye on his Instagram for updates. Find originals and prints in his shop.

¬†

‚ÄúDrift,‚Äù 12 x 9 inches

‚ÄúThe Right Grape,‚Äù 9 x 12 inches

‚ÄúSuccumb,‚Äù 6 x 8 inches

‚ÄúLightning,‚Äù 6 x 8 inches

‚ÄúFramed II,‚Äù 8 x 10 inches

‚ÄúLook Around,‚Äù 10 x 10 inches

‚ÄúSleepy,‚Äù 6 x 8 inches

item.content:encoded:

item.title: Apple Introduces OpenELM: Open-Source AI Models for On-Device Processing
item.dc:creator: ross
item.description: Apple has recently unveiled OpenELM, a family of open-source language models optimized for on-device processing. This model has been made open source, encouraging free usage and collaboration. Apple‚Äôs move towards transparency aims to empower developers and researchers while enhancing user privacy. Let‚Äôs find out more about this new release. Also Read: Apple Boosts AI Capabilities […]
item.content:encoded:
Apple has recently unveiled OpenELM, a family of open-source language models optimized for on-device processing. This model has been made open source, encouraging free usage and collaboration. Apple‚Äôs move towards transparency aims to empower developers and researchers while enhancing user privacy. Let‚Äôs find out more about this new release. Also Read: Apple Boosts AI Capabilities [‚Ä¶]

item.title: St√©phane Thidet Challenges Physics and Social Norms in His Site-Specific Installations
item.dc:creator: ross
item.description: ‚ÄúRideau‚Äù (2020), in situ installation at Th√©√¢tre Graslin, Nantes, France, water, pumps, pond installation in situ. Photo ¬© Martin Argyroglo, courtesy of the artist and Galerie Aline Vidal. All images shared with permission Paris-based artist¬†St√©phane Thidet invites viewers into wondrous worlds that skew perceptions and distort the laws of physics: a small wooden boat appears […]
item.content:encoded:
‚ÄúRideau‚Äù (2020), in situ installation at Th√©√¢tre Graslin, Nantes, France, water, pumps, pond installation in situ. Photo ¬© Martin Argyroglo, courtesy of the artist and Galerie Aline Vidal. All images shared with permission

Paris-based artist¬†St√©phane Thidet invites viewers into wondrous worlds that skew perceptions and distort the laws of physics: a small wooden boat appears to arise from hard planks, flat stones nest inside a bookcase where paper tomes once stood, and water cascades from a Nantes theater making it impossible to enter without being drenched. Crafted with familiar materials and subject matter, Thidet‚Äôs site-specific installations and sculptures twist common scenes into unexpected territories.

Explore an archive of the artist‚Äôs work on his website.

¬†

‚ÄúChair‚Äù (2009), chairs, wood shavings, and sawdust, variable dimensions. Photo ¬© St√©phane Thidet, courtesy of the artist and Galerie Aline Vidal

‚ÄúLa Crue‚Äù (2010), poplar wood, nails, variable dimensions. Photo ¬© Galerie Aline Vidal courtesy of the artist and Galerie Aline Vidal Collection MAC VAL

‚ÄúRideau‚Äù (2020), in situ installation at Th√©√¢tre Graslin, Nantes, France, water, pumps, pond installation in situ. Photo ¬© Martin Argyroglo, courtesy of the artist and Galerie Aline Vidal

‚ÄúSans titre (Je crois qu‚Äôil y avait une maison, il me semble y avoir v√©cu)‚Äù (2010), bookcase and white stones, 239 x 187 centimeters. Photo ¬© St√©phane Thidet, courtesy of the artist and Galerie Aline Vidal Collection CNAP

‚ÄúIl n‚Äôest pas de nouveau monde‚Äù (2023), wood and steel, 300 x 550 x 400 centimeters. Photo ¬© Cit√© internationale de la langue Fran√ßaise, courtesy of the artist and Galerie Aline Vidal
